articles.headline: U.S. Toughens Its Position on China Trade
articles.snippet: Taking China to court over suspected trade barriers and piracy was seen as necessary to send a signal to Beijing.
articles.abstract: Taking China to court over suspected trade barriers and piracy was seen as necessary to send a signal to Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 9 — Has the Bush administration’s economic team run out of patience with China?

articles.headline: Pfizer Drug for Diabetes Is Lagging
articles.snippet: Wall Street analysts are cutting their sales estimates for Exubera, which has been dogged by questions about its safety, cost and convenience.
articles.abstract: Wall Street analysts are cutting their sales estimates for Exubera, which has been dogged by questions about its safety, cost and convenience.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exubera, the first and so far only commercially available inhaled-insulin diabetes treatment, is on the verge of turning into an expensive failure for its maker, Pfizer.

articles.headline: A Photo Trove, a Mounting Challenge
articles.snippet: The new chief executive for Corbis is expected to respond to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its sales.
articles.abstract: The new chief executive for Corbis is expected to respond to the rise of low-cost online rivals that threaten to undermine its sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: In some sense, the iconic photograph of Rosa Parks recreating her quiet act of rebellion on a bus in Montgomery, Ala., belongs to every American. But as a practical matter, it belongs to Bill Gates.

articles.headline: Huge Protest in Iraq Demands U.S. Withdraw
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of protesters loyal to Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr demanded an end to the American military presence in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of protesters loyal to Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr demanded an end to the American military presence in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 9 — Tens of thousands of protesters loyal to Moktada al-Sadr, the Shiite cleric, took to the streets of the holy city of Najaf on Monday in an extraordinarily disciplined rally to demand an end to the American military presence in Iraq, burning American flags and chanting “Death to America!”

articles.headline: High Stakes: Chávez Plays the Oil Card
articles.snippet: A showdown between President Hugo Chávez and U.S. and European companies over key oil projects could wind up with all sides losing.
articles.abstract: A showdown between President Hugo Chávez and U.S. and European companies over key oil projects could wind up with all sides losing.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 9 — With President Hugo Chávez setting a May 1 deadline for an ambitious plan to wrest control of several major oil projects from American and European companies, a showdown is looming here over access to some of the most coveted energy resources outside the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Report of Talk to Take Over Bell Canada
articles.snippet: The $45 billion takeover bid from a consortium led by a Canadian pension fund would be the largest buyout in history.
articles.abstract: The $45 billion takeover bid from a consortium led by a Canadian pension fund would be the largest buyout in history.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of Canada’s largest pension funds is in early talks with other investors to form a consortium to mount a $45 billion takeover bid for the parent company of Bell Canada in what would be the largest buyout in history, according to people briefed on the discussions.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Defaults Rise in Next Level of Mortgages
articles.snippet: American Home Mortgage said it would pay out a smaller dividend because it was being asked to buy back and write down certain loans.
articles.abstract: American Home Mortgage said it would pay out a smaller dividend because it was being asked to buy back and write down certain loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the problems afflicting mortgages sold to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit increasingly appear to be cropping up in loans made to homeowners who were thought to be less risky.

articles.headline: Training to Be Old
articles.snippet: While financial planning is important, there are also psychological and physical implications to retirement preparation.
articles.abstract: While financial planning is important, there are also psychological and physical implications to retirement preparation.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT 55, Frank Mendizabal has no immediate plan to leave his executive job at the Weyerhaeuser Company. And his finances are in good shape for when he does.

articles.headline: Radio Host Is Suspended Over Racial Remarks
articles.snippet: Don Imus agreed that the suspension was appropriate and promised to change the tenor of his show, MSNBC said.
articles.abstract: Don Imus agreed that the suspension was appropriate and promised to change the tenor of his show, MSNBC said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The radio talk show host Don Imus was suspended for two weeks yesterday after the outcry over his racially disparaging remarks about the Rutgers University women’s basketball team.

articles.headline: DNA Tests Offer Immigrants Hope or Despair
articles.snippet: Genetic tests are forcing some immigrant families to confront unexpected and sometimes unbearable truths.
articles.abstract: Genetic tests are forcing some immigrant families to confront unexpected and sometimes unbearable truths.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS  For 14 years, Isaac Owusu’s faraway boys have tugged at his heart. They sent report cards from his hometown in Ghana and painstaking letters in fledgling English while he scrimped and saved to bring them here one day.
